sp.p: Mrs. Abigal is withdrawn.—I was in hopes to have heard what paſs'd between her and her inviſible Correſpondent.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [aſide.] Vellum! We are methinks very familiar; I am not us'd to be call'd ſo by any but their Ho—nours—What wou'd you, Mr. Tinſel?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Let me beg a Favour of thee, old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: What is that, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Prithee run and fetch me the Rent-Roll of thy Lady's Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: The Rent-roll?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: The Rent-roll? Ay, the Rent-roll! Doſt not underſtand what that means?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Why? have you Thoughts of purchaſing of it?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou haſt hit it, old Boy; that is my very Intention.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: The Purchaſe will be conſiderable.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: And for that reaſon I have bid thy Lady very high—She is to have no leſs for it than this entire Perſon of mine.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Is your whole Eſtate Perſonal, Mr. Tinſel—he, he, he!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why, you queer old Dog, you don't pretend to jeſt, d'ye? Look ye, Vellum, if you think of being continued my Steward, you muſt learn to walk with your Toes out.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [Aſide.] An inſolent Companion!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou'rt confounded rich, I ſee, by that Dangling of thy Arms.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [Aſide.] An ungracious Bird!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt lend me a couple of Thouſand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [Aſide.] A very Profligate!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Look ye, Vellum, I intend to be kind to you—I'll borrow ſome Mony of you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I cannot but ſmile to conſider the Diſappointment this young Fellow will meet with; I will make my ſelf merry with him. [Aſide.] And ſo, Mr. Tinſel, you promiſe you will be a very kind Maſter to me?[Stifling a Laugh.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: What will you give for a Life in the Houſe you live in?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: What do you think of Five Hundred Pounds?—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: That's too little.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: And yet it is more than I ſhall give you—And I will offer you two Reaſons for it.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Prithee what are they?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Firſt, becauſe the Tenement is not in your Diſpoſal; and Secondly, becauſe it never will be in your Diſpoſal; and ſo fare you well, good Mr. Tinſel. Ha, ha, ha! You will pardon me for being jocular.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: This Rogue is as ſaucy as the Conjurer; I'll be hang'd if they are not a-kin.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Tinſel! what, all alone? You Free-thinkers are great Admirers of Solitude.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: No faith, I have been talking with thy Steward; a very groteſque Figure of a Fellow, the very Picture of one of our Benchers. How can you bear his Converſation?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I keep him for my Steward, and not my Companion. He's a ſober Man.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he looks like a Put—a queer old Dog, as ever I ſaw in my Life: We muſt turn him off, Widow. He cheats thee confoundedly, I ſee that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed you're miſtaken, he has always had the Reputation of being a very honeſt Man.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: What? I ſuppoſe he goes to Church.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Goes to Church! ſo do you too, I hope.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I wou'd for once, Widow, to make ſure of you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Tinſel, a Husband who would not continue to go thither, wou'd quickly forget the Promiſes he made there.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Faith very innocent and very ridiculous! Well then, I warrant thee, Widow, thou wou'dſt not for the World marry a Sabbath-breaker!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Truly they generally come to a bad End. I remember the Conjurer told you, you were ſhort-liv'd.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: The Conjurer! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed you're very witty!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Indeed you're very handſome.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I wiſh the Fool does not love me! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou art the Idol I adore. Here muſt I pay my Devotion—Prithee, Widow, haſt thou any Timber upon thy Eſtate?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The moſt impudent Fellow I ever met with. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I take Notice thou haſt a great deal of old Plate here in the Houſe, Widow.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Tinſel, you are a very obſerving Man.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thy large Silver Ciſtern would make a very good Coach, and half a Dozen Salvers that I ſaw on the Side-board, might be turn'd into ſix as pretty Horſes as any that appear in the Ring.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You have a very good Fancy, Mr. Tinſel—What pretty Transformations you could make in my Houſe—But I'll ſee where 'twill end. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Then I obſerve, Child, you have two or three Services of gilt Plate; we'd eat always in China, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I perceive you are an excellent Manager—How quickly you have taken an Inventory of my Goods!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Now hark ye, Widow, to ſhow you the Love that I have for you—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Very well, let me hear.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: You have an old-faſhion'd Gold Caudle-Cup, with the Figure of a Saint upon the Lid on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have, what then?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why look ye, I'd ſell the Caudle-Cup with the old Saint for as much Money as they'd fetch, which I wou'd convert into a Diamond Buckle, and make you a Preſent of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh you are generous to an Extravagance. But pray, Mr. Tinſel, don't diſpoſe of my Goods before you are ſure of my Perſon. I find you have taken a great Affection to my Moveables.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: My Dear, I love every thing that belongs to you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſee you do, Sir, you need not make any Proteſtations upon that Subject.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Pho, pho, my Dear, we are growing Serious; and, let me tell you, that's the very next Step to being Dull. Come, that pretty Face was never made to look grave with.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, whatever you may think, Marriage is a ſerious Subject.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: For that very Reaſon, my Dear, let us get over it as faſt as we can.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſhould be very much in haſte for a Husband, if I married within fourteen Months after Sir George's Deceaſe.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Pray, my Dear, let me ask you a Queſtion; Do'ſt not thou think that Sir George is as dead at preſent, to all Intents and Purpoſes, as he will be a Twelve-month hence?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, but Decency! Mr. Tinſel—

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Or do'ſt thou think thou'lt be more a Widow then, than thou art now?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The World would ſay I never lov'd my Firſt Husband.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ah, my Dear, they wou'd ſay you lov'd your Second; and they wou'd own I deſerv'd it, for I ſhall love thee moſt inordinately.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But what wou'd People think?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Think! why they wou'd think thee the Mirrour of Widowhood.—That a Woman ſhou'd live fourteen whole Months after the Deceaſe of her Spouſe, without having engaged herſelf. Why, about Town, we know many a Woman of Quality's Second Husband ſeveral Years before the Death of the Firſt.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, I know you Wits have your common-place Jeſts upon us poor Widows.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I'll tell you a Story, Widow; I know a certain Lady, who conſidering the Crazineſs of her Husband, had, in caſe of Mortality, engaged her ſelf to two young Fellows of my Acquaintance. They grew ſuch deſperate Rivals for her, while her Husband was alive, that one of them pink'd the t'other in a Duel. But the good Lady was no ſooner a Widow, but what did my Dowager do? Why faith, being a Woman of Honour, ſhe married a Third, to whom, it ſeems, ſhe had given her firſt Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And this is a true Story upon your own Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Every Tittle, as I hope to be marry'd, or never believe Tom Tinſel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Tinſel, do you call this talking like a Wit, or like a Rake?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Innocent enough, he, he, he! Why! where's the Difference, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Tinſel, the only Man I ever lov'd in my Life, had a great deal of the one, and nothing of the other in him.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Nay now you grow vapouriſh; thou'lt begin to fancy thou hear'ſt the Drum by and by.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you had been here laſt Night about this time, you would not have been ſo merry.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: About this time, ſay'ſt thou? Come faith, for the Humour's ſake, we'll ſit down and liſten.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will, if you'll promiſe to be ſerious.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Serious! never fear me, Child. Ha, ha, ha! Do'ſt not hear him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You break your World already. Pray, Mr. Tinſel, do you laugh to ſhow your Wit or your Teeth?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why, both! my Dear.—I'm glad, however, that ſhe has taken notice of my Teeth. [Aſide.] But you look ſerious, Child; I fancy thou hear'ſt the Drum, do'ſt not?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Don't talk ſo raſhly?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why, my Dear, you cou'd not look more frighted if you had Lucifer's Drum-Major in your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Tinſel, I muſt deſire to ſee you no more in it, if you do not leave this idle way of Talking.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Child, I thought I had told you what is my Opinion of Spirits, as we were drinking a diſh of Tea but juſt now.—There is no ſuch thing I give thee my Word.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Tinſel, your Authority muſt be of great weight to thoſe that know you.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: For my part, Child, I have made my ſelf eaſy in thoſe Points.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sure nothing was ever like this Fellow's Vanity, but his Ignorance. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I'll tell thee what now, Widow—I wou'd engage by the help of a white Sheet and a penny-worth of Link in a dark Night, to frighten you a whole Country Village out of their Sences, and the Vicar into the bargain. [Drum beats.] Hark! hark! what Noiſe is that! Heaven defend us! this is more than Fancy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It beats more terrible than ever.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: 'Tis very dreadful! What a Dog have I been to ſpeak againſt my Conſcience, only to ſhow my Parts!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It comes nearer and nearer. I wiſh you have not anger'd it by your fooliſh Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I did not ſpeak from my Heart; I hope it will do me no hurt, for a little harmleſs Raillery.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Harmleſs, d'ye call it? it beats hard by us, as if it wou'd break through the Wall.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: What a Devil had I to do with a white Sheet?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Mercy on us! it appears.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis he! 'tis he himſelf, 'tis Sir George! 'tis my Husband.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Now wou'd I give Ten Thouſand Pound that I were in Town.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I beg Ten Thouſand Pardons. I'll never talk at this rate any more.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p:
By my Soul, Sir George, I was not in earneſt [falls on his knees] have Compaſſion on my Youth, and conſider I am but a Coxcomb— [Fantome points to the Door.] But ſee he
waves me off—ay with all my Heart—What a Devil had I to do with a white Sheet?
sp.stage: [He ſteals off the Stage, mending his Pace as the Drum beats.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: The Scoundrel is gone, and has left his Miſtreſs behind him. I'm miſtaken if he makes Love in this Houſe any more. I have now only the Conjurer to deal with. I don't queſtion but I ſhall make his Reverence ſcamper as faſt as the Lover. And then the Day's my own. But the Servants are coming. I muſt get into my Cup-board.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh my poor Lady! This wicked Drum has frighted Mr. Tinſel out of his Wits, and my Lady into a Swoon. Let me bend her a little forward. She revives. Here, carry her into the freſh Air and ſhe'll recover. [They carry her off.] This is a little barbarous to my Lady, but 'tis all for her Good: and I know her ſo well, that ſhe wou'd not be angry with me, if ſhe knew what I was to get by it. And if any of her Friends ſhou'd blame me for it hereafter,
sp.l: I'll clap my Hand upon my Purſe, and tell 'em,
'Twas for a thouſand Pound and Mr. Vellum.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir George, in his Conjurer's Habit, the Butler marching before him with two large Candles, and the two Servants coming after him, one bringing a little Table, and another a Chair.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: AN't pleaſe your Worſhip, Mr. Conjurer, the Steward has given all of us Orders to do whatſoever you ſhall bid us, and to pay you the ſame Reſpect, as if you were our Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Thou ſay'ſt well.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Conjurerſhip's Worſhip, ſhall I ſet the Table down here?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Here, Peter.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Peter!—He knows my Name by his Learning. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I have brought you, Reverend Sir, the largeſt Elbow Chair in the Houſe; 'tis that the Steward ſits in when he holds a Court.

sp.speaker: Sir G:
sp.p: Place it there.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, will you pleaſe to want any thing elſe?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Paper, and a Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, I believe we have Paper that is fit for your Purpoſe! My Lady's mourning Paper, that is black'd at the Edges—Wou'd you chuſe to write with a Crow Quill?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: There is none better.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Coachman, go fetch the Paper and Standiſh out of the little Parlour.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: [To Gard.] Peter, prithee do thou go along with me—I'm afraid—You know I went with you laſt Night into the Garden, when the Cook-Maid wanted a handful of Parſley.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why, you don't think I'll ſtay with the Conjurer by my ſelf!

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Come, we'll all three go and fetch the Pen and Ink together.

sp.speaker: Sir G. ſolus.
sp.p: There's nothing, I ſee, makes ſuch ſtrong Alliances as Fear. Theſe Fellows are all enter'd into a Confederacy againſt the Ghoſt. There muſt be abundance of Buſineſs done in the Family at this rate. But here comes the Triple-Alliance. Who cou'd have thought theſe three Rogues cou'd have found each of 'em an Employment in fetching a Pen and Ink!

div.stage: Enter Gardiner with a Sheet of Paper, Coachman with a Standiſh, and Butler with a Pen.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Sir, there is your Paper.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Sir, there is your Standiſh.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, there is your Crow-quill Pen—I'm glad I have got rid on't. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: [Aſide.] He forgets that he's to make a Circle—Doctor, ſhall I help you to a Bit of Chalk?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: It is no matter.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, I ſhow'd you the Spot where he's heard ofteneſt, if your Worſhip can but ferret him out of that old Wall in the next Room—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: We ſhall try.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: That's right, John. His Worſhip muſt let fly all his Learning at that old Wall.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, if I was worthy to adviſe you, I wou'd have a Bottle of good October by me. Shall I ſet a Cup of old Stingo at your Elbow?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I thank thee—we ſhall do without it.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: John, he ſeems a very good-natur'd Man for a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I'll take this Opportunity of enquiring after a Bit of Plate I have loſt. I fancy, whilſt he is in my Lady's Pay, one may hedge in a Queſtion or two into the Bargain. Sir, Sir, may I beg a word in your Ear?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, I know I need not tell you, that I loſt one of my Silver Spoons laſt Week.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Mark'd with a Swan's Neck—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My Lady's Creſt! He knows every thing. [Aſide.] How wou'd your Worſhip adviſe me to recover it again?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What muſt I do to come at it?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Drink nothing but Small-Beer for a Fortnight—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Small Beer! Rot-gut!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: If thou drink'ſt a ſingle Drop of Ale before fifteen Days are expir'd—it is as much—as thy Spoon—is worth.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I ſhall never recover it that way; I'll e'en buy a new one. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: D'ye mind how they whiſper?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if he be not asking him ſomething about Nell—

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I'll take this Opportunity of putting a Queſtion to him about poor Dobbing: I fancy he cou'd give me better Council than the Farrier.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: [to Gard.] A prodigious Man! he knows every thing: Now is the time to find out thy Pick-ax.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I have nothing to give him: Does not he expect to have his Hand croſs'd with Silver?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: [to Sir G.] Sir, may a Man venture to ask you a Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ask it.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I have a poor Horſe in the Stable that's bewitch'd—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A bay Gelding.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: How cou'd he know that?— [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Bought at Banbury.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Whew—ſo it was o' my Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Six Year old laſt Lammas.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: To a Day. [Aſide.] Now, Sir, I wou'd know whether the poor Beaſt is bewitch'd by Goody Crouch or Goody Flye?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Then it muſt be Goody Gurton! for ſhe is the next oldeſt Woman in the Pariſh.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ha'ſt thou done, Robin?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: [to Gard.] He can tell thee any thing.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: [to Sir G.] Sir, I wou'd beg to take you a little further out of hearing——

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Speak.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: The Butler and I, Mr. Doctor, were both of us in Love at the ſame time with a certain Perſon.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A Woman.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: How cou'd he know that! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: This Woman has lately had two Children at a Birth.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Twins.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Prodigious! where could he hear that? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Now, becauſe I us'd to meet her ſometimes in the Garden, ſhe has laid them both—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: To Thee.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: What a Power of Learning he muſt have! he knows every thing. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ha'ſt thou done?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I wou'd deſire to know whether I am really Father to them both?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Stand before me, let me ſurvey thee round.
sp.stage: [Lays his Wand upon his Head, and makes him turn about.]

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Look yonder, John, the ſilly Dog is turning about under the Conjurer's Wand. If he has been ſaucy to him, we ſhall ſee him puff'd off in a Whirlwind immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Twins, do'ſt thou ſay?[Still turning him.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ay, are they both mine d'ye think?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Own but one of them.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ah, but Mrs. Abigal will have me take care of them both—ſhe's always for the Butler—If my poor Maſter Sir George had been alive, he wou'd have made him go Halves with me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: What, was Sir George a kind Maſter?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Was he! Ay, my Fellow-Servants will bear me Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Did ye love Sir George?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Every Body lov'd him—

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: There was not a dry Eye in the Pariſh at the News of his Death—

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: He was the beſt Neighbour—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The kindeſt Husband—

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: The trueſt Friend to the Poor—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My good Lady took on mightily, we all thought it wou'd have been the Death of her——

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I proteſt theſe Fellows melt me! I think the time long till I am their Maſter again, that I may be kind to them. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Have you provided the Doctor ev'ry thing he has Occaſion for? if ſo,—you may depart.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I can as yet ſee no hurt in my Wife's Behaviour; but ſtill have ſome certain Pangs and Doubts, that are natural to the Heart of a fond Man. I muſt take the Advantage of my Diſguiſe to be thoroughly ſatisfied. It wou'd neither be for her Happineſs, nor mine, to make my ſelf known to her till I am ſo [Aſide.] Dear Vellum! I am impatient to hear ſome News of my Wife, how does ſhe after her Fright?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is a Saying ſomewhere in my Lord Coke, that a Widow—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I ask of my Wife, and thou talk'ſt to me of my Lord Coke—prithee tell me how ſhe does, for I am in Pain for her.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: She is pretty well recover'd Mrs. Abigal has put her in good Heart; and I have given her great hopes from your Skill.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: That I think cannot fail, ſince thou haſt got this Secret out of Abigal! But I could not have thought my Friend Fantome would have ſerved me thus—

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You will ſtill fancy you are a living Man—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: That he ſhou'd endeavour to Enſnare my Wife—

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You have no Right in her, after your Demiſe Death extinguiſhes all Property,—Quoad hanc—It is a Maxim in the Law.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A Pox on your Learning! Well, but what is become of Tinſel?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He ruſh'd out of the Houſe, call'd for his Horſe, clap'd Spurs to his ſides, and was out of ſight in leſs time, than I—can—tell—ten.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: This is Whimſical enough! my Wife will have a quick Succeſſion of Lovers, in one Day—Fantome has driven out Tinſel, and I ſhall drive out Fantome.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Ev'n as one Wedge driveth out another—he, he, he! you muſt pardon me for being Jocular.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a provoking Blockhead! but he means me well.—Well! I muſt have Satisfaction of this Traitour Fantome; and cannot take a more proper one, than by turning him out of my Houſe, in a manner that ſhall throw Shame upon him, and make him ridiculous as long as he lives.—You muſt remember, Vellum, you have abundance of Buſineſs upon your Hands, and I have but juſt time to tell it you over, all I require of you is Diſpatch, therefore hear me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: There is nothing more requiſite in Buſineſs than Diſpatch—

sp.speaker: Sir. G.
sp.p: Then hear me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is indeed the Life of Buſineſs—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hear Me then, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: And as one has rightly obſerved, the Benefit that attends it is four-fold. Firſt—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: There is no bearing this! Thou art a going to deſcribe Diſpatch, when thou ſhouldſt be practiſing it.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But your Ho—nour will not give me the hearing—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Thou wilt not give me the hearing. [Angrily.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I am ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: In the Firſt place, you are to lay my Wigg, Hat, and Sword ready for me in the Cloſet, and one of my Scarlet Coats. You know how Abigal has deſcribed the Ghoſt to you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Then you muſt remember, whilſt I am laying this Ghoſt, you are to prepare my Wife for the Reception of her real Husband; tell her the whole Story, and do it with all the Art you are Maſter of, that the Surpriſe may not be too great for her.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It ſhall be done—But ſince her Ho—nour has ſeen this Apparition, ſhe deſires to ſee you once more, before you encounter it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I ſhall expect her impatiently. For now I can talk to her without being interrupted by that impertinent Rogue Tinſel. I hope thou haſt not told Abigal any thing of the Secret.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal is a Woman; there are many Reaſons why ſhe ſhou'd not be acquainted with it: I ſhall only mention Six—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Huſh, here ſhe comes! Oh my Heart!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: [Aſide, while Vellum talks in dumb Show to Lady.] O that lov'd Woman! How I long to take her in my Arms! If I find I am ſtill Dear to her Memory, it will be a return to Life indeed! But I muſt take care of indulging this Tenderneſs, and put on a Behaviour more ſuitable to my preſent Character.
sp.stage: [Walks at a diſtance in a penſive Poſture, waving his Wand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: [to Vellum.] This is ſurprizing indeed! So all the Servants tell me; They ſay he knows every thing that has happen'd in the Family.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [Aſide.] A parcel of credulous Fools! They firſt tell him their Secrets, and then wonder how he comes to know them.
sp.stage: [Exit Vellum, exchanging fond Looks with Abigal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Learned Sir, may I have ſome Converſation with you, before you begin your Ceremonies?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Speak! But hold—firſt let me feel your Pulſe?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What can you learn from that?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I have already learn'd a Secret from it, that will aſtoniſh you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, what is it?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: You will have a Husband within this half Hour.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I'm glad to hear that—He muſt mean Mr. Fantome; I begin to think there's a good deal of Truth in his Art.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alas! I fear you mean I ſhall ſee Sir George's Apparition a ſecond time.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Have Courage, you ſhall ſee the Apparition no more. The Husband I mention ſhall be as much alive as I am.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Mr. Fantome to be ſure. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Impoſſible! I lov'd my firſt too well.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: You cou'd not love the firſt better than you will love the ſecond.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I'll be hang'd if my dear Steward has not inſtructed him; he means Mr. Fantome to be ſure; the Thouſand Pound is our own!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alas! you did not know Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir G
sp.p: As well as I do my ſelf—I ſaw him with you in the red Damask Room, when he firſt made Love to you; your Mother left you together, under Pretence of receiving a Viſit from Mrs. Hawthorn, on her Return from London.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: You were a great Admirer of a ſingle Life for the firſt half Hour; your Refuſals then grew ſtill fainter and fainter. With what Extaſy did Sir George kiſs your Hand, when you told him you ſhou'd always follow the Advice of your Mamma!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Every Circumſtance to a Tittle!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Then, Lady! the Wedding Night! I ſaw you in your white Sattin Night-gown; you wou'd not come out of your Dreſſing-Room, till Sir George took you out by Force. He drew you gently by the Hand—You ſtruggled—but he was too ſtrong for you—You bluſh'd, He—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! ſtop there! go no farther!—He knows every thing. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Conjurer, I believe you have been a Wagg in your Youth.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal, you know what your good Word coſt Sir George, a Purſe of Broad Pieces, Mrs. Abigal—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: The Devil's in him. [Aſide.] Pray, Sir, ſince you have told ſo far, you ſhould tell my Lady that I refus'd to take them.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Child, he was forc'd to thruſt them into your Boſome.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p:
This Rogue will mention the Thouſand Pound, if I don't
take care [Aſide.] Pray, Sir, tho' you are a Conjurer, methinks you need not be a Blab—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, ſince I have now no Reaſon to doubt of your Art, I muſt beſeech you to treat this Apparition gently—It has the reſemblance of my deceas'd Husband, if there be any undiſcover'd Secret, any thing that troubles his Reſt, learn it of him.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I muſt to that End be ſincerely informed by you, whether your Heart be engaged to another; Have not you receiv'd the Addreſſes of many Lovers ſince his Death?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have been oblig'd to receive more Viſits, than have been agreeable.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Was not Tinſel welcome?—I'm afraid to hear an Anſwer to my own Queſtion. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He was well recommended.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Racks! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Of a good Family.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Tortures! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Heir to a conſiderable Eſtate!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Death! [Aſide] And you ſtill love him?—I'm Diſtracted! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, I deſpiſe him. I found he had a deſign upon my Fortune, was Baſe, Profligate, Cowardly, and ev'ry thing that cou'd be expected from a Man of the vileſt Principles!—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I'm Recover'd.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, had you ſeen how like a Scoundrel he look'd when he left your Ladyſhip in a Swoon. Where have you left my Lady? ſays I. In an Elbow-Chair, Child, ſays he. And where are you going? ſays I. To Town, Child, ſays he: For to tell thee truly, Child, ſays he, I don't care for living under the ſame Roof with the Devil, ſays he.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Well, Lady, I ſee nothing in all this, that may hinder Sir George's Spirit from being at Reſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: If he knows any thing of what paſſes in my Heart, he cannot but be ſatisfy'd of that Fondneſs which I bear to his Memory. My Sorrow for him is always freſh when I think of him. He was the kindeſt, trueſt, tendereſt—Tears will not let me go on—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p:
This quite o'erpowers me—I ſhall diſcover my ſelf
before my time. [Aſide.]—Madam, you may now retire and leave to me my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Succeſs attend you!

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: I wiſh Mr. Fantome gets well off from this old Don—I know he'll be with him immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: My Heart is now at Eaſe, ſhe is the ſame dear Woman I left her—Now for my Revenge upon Fantome.—I ſhall cut the Ceremonies ſhort—A few Words will do his Buſineſs—Now let me ſeat my ſelf in form.—A good eaſy Chair for a Conjurer this!—Now for a few Mathematical Scratches—a good lucky Scrawl, that—faith I think it looks very Aſtrological—Theſe two or three magical Pot-hooks about it, make it a compleat Conjurer's Scheme. [Drum beats] Ha, ha, ha, Sir, are you there? Enter Drummer. Now muſt I pore upon my Paper.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Prithee don't make a Noiſe, I'm buſy.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A pretty March! prithee beat that over again.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: [Riſing] Ha! you're very perfect in the Step of a Ghoſt. You ſtalk it Majeſtically.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: How the Rogue ſtares, he acts it to Admiration; I'll be hang'd if he has not been practiſing this half hour in Mrs. Abigal's Wardrobe.
sp.stage: [Fantome ſtarts, gives a rap upon his Drum.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Prithee don't play the Fool!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Nay, nay, enough of this good Mr. Fantome.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: [Aſide.] Death! I'm diſcover'd. This Jade Abigal has betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Mr. Fantome, upon the Word of an Aſtrologer, your Thouſand Pound Bribe will never gain my Lady Truman.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: 'Tis plain, She has told him all. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Let me adviſe you to make off as faſt as you can, or I plainly perceive by my Art, Mr. Ghoſt will have his Bones broke.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: [to Sir G.] Look'ye, Old Gentleman, I perceive you have learnt this Secret from Mrs. Abigal.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I have learn'd it from my Art.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Thy Art! prithee no more of that. Look ye, I know you are a Cheat as much as I am. And if thou'lt keep my Counſel, I'll give thee ten Broad Pieces.—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I am not Mercenary! Young Man, I ſcorn thy Gold.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I'll make them up Twenty.—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Avaunt! and that quickly, or I'll raiſe ſuch an Apparition, as ſhall—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: An Apparition, Old Gentleman! you miſtake your Man, I am not to be frighten'd with Bugbears.—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Let me retire but for a few Moments, and I will give thee ſuch a Proof of my Art—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Why, if thou haſt any Hocus-pocus Tricks to play, why canſt not do them here?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: The raiſing of a Spirit, requires certain Secret Myſteries to be performed, and Words to be mutter'd in private.—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Well, if I ſee through your Trick, will you promiſe to be my Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I will—attend and tremble.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: A very ſolemn old Aſs! But I ſmoak him,—he has a mind to raiſe his Price upon me. I cou'd not think this Slut wou'd have us'd me thus.—I begin to grow horribly tir'd of my Drum, I wiſh I was well rid of it. However I have got this by it, that it has driven off Tinſel for good and all; I ſhan't have the Mortification to ſee my Miſtreſs carry'd off by ſuch a Rival, Well, whatever happens, I muſt ſtop this Old Fellow's Mouth, I muſt not be ſparing in Huſh-Money. But here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Sir George in his own Habit.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Ha! what's that! Sir George Truman! This can be no Counterfeit. His Dreſs! his Shape! his Face! the very Wound of which he dy'd! Nay, then 'tis time to decamp!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Fare you well, good Sir George—The Enemy has left me Maſter of the Field: Here are the Marks of my Victory. This Drum will I hang up in my great Hall as the Trophy of the Day.

div.stage: Sir George ſtands with his Hand before his Face in a muſing Poſture.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Yonder he is. O' my Conſcience he has driven off the Conjurer. Mr. Fantome, Mr. Fantome! I give you Joy, I give you Joy. What do you think of your Thouſand Pounds now? Why does not the Man ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ha! [Taking his Hand from his Face.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis my Maſter! [Shrieks.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Abigal not ſo faſt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Are you alive, Sir? He has given my Shoulder ſuch a curſed Tweak! they muſt be real Fingers. I feel 'em I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: What do'ſt think?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Think, Sir? Think? Troth I don't know what to think. Pray, Sir, how—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: No Queſtions, good Abigal. Thy Curioſity ſhall be ſatisfied in due time. Where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, I'm ſo frighted—and ſo glad!—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Where's your Lady, I ask you—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Marry I don't know where I am my ſelf—I can't forbear weeping for Joy—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Your Lady! I ſay your Lady! I muſt bring you to your ſelf with one Pinch more—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh! ſhe has been talking a good while with the Steward.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Then he has open'd the whole Story to her, I'm glad he has prepar'd her. Oh! here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where is he? let me fly into his Arms! my Life! my Soul! my Husband!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Oh! let me catch thee to my Heart, deareſt of Women!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are you then ſtill alive, and are you here! I can ſcarce believe my Senſes! Now am I happy indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: My Heart is too full to anſwer thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
How could you be ſo cruel to defer giving me that Joy which you knew I muſt receive from your Preſence? You have
robb'd my Life of ſome Hours of Happineſs that ought to have been in it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: It was to make our Happineſs the more ſincere and unmixt. There will be now no Doubts to daſh it. What has been the Affliction of our Lives, has given a Variety to them, and will hereafter ſupply us with a thouſand Materials to talk of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am now ſatisfy'd that it is not in the Power of Abſence to leſſen your Love towards me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: And I am ſatisfy'd that it is not in the Power of Death to deſtroy that Love which makes me the happieſt of Men.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Was ever Woman ſo bleſt! to find again the Darling of her Soul, when ſhe thought him loſt for ever! to enter into a kind of ſecond Marriage with the only Man whom ſhe was ever capable of loving!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: May it be as happy as our firſt, I deſire no more! Believe me, my Dear, I want Words to expreſs thoſe Tranſports of Joy and Tenderneſs which are every Moment riſing in my Heart whilſt I ſpeak to thee.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Juſt as the Steward told us, Lads! Look you there, if he ben't with my Lady already?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: He! he! he! what a joyful Night will this be for Madam!

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: As I was coming in at the Gate, a ſtrange Gentleman whisk'd by me; but he took to his Heels, and made away to the George. If I did not ſee Maſter before me, I ſhou'd have ſworn it had been his Honour!

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ha'ſt given Orders for the Bells to be ſet a ringing?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Never trouble thy Head about that, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: [to Lady.] My Dear, I long as much to tell you my whole Story, as you do to hear it. In the mean while, I am to look upon this as my Wedding Day. I'll have nothing but the Voice of Mirth and Feaſting in my Houſe. My poor Neighbours and my Servants ſhall rejoyce with me. My Hall ſhall be free to every one, and let my Cellars be thrown open.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ah! bleſs your Honour, may you never die again!

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: The ſame good Man that ever he was!

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Whurra!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Vellum, thou haſt done me much Service to Day. I know thou lov'ſt Abigal, but ſhe's diſappointed in a Fortune. I'll make it up to both of you. I'll give thee a Thouſand Pound with her. It is not fit there ſhou'd be one ſad Heart in my Houſe to Night.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What you do for Abigal, I know is meant as a Compliment to me. This is a new Inſtance of your Love.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Mr. Vellum, you are a well-ſpoken Man: Pray do you thank my Maſter and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Vellum, I hope you are not diſpleas'd with the Gift I make you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: The Gift is Twofold. I receive from you
A virtuous Partner, and a Portion too;
For which, in humble wiſe, I thank the Donors:
And ſo we bid Good-night to both your Ho—nours.

lg.l: TO Night, the Poet's Advocate I ſtand,
And he deſerves the Favour at my hand,
Who in my Equipage their Cauſe debating
Has plac'd two Lovers, and a third in waiting;
If both the firſt ſhou'd from their Duty ſwerve,
There's one behind the Wainſcote in reſerve.
In his next Play, if I wou'd take this Trouble,
He promis'd me to make the Number double:
In troth 'twas ſpoke like an obliging Creature,
For tho' 'tis Simple, yet it ſhews Good-nature.
My Help thus ask'd, I cou'd not chuſe but grant it,
And really I thought the Play wou'd want it,
Void as it is of all the uſual Arts
To warm your Fancies, and to ſteal your Hearts:
No Court-Intrigue, nor City-Cuckoldom,
No Song, no Dance, no Muſick—but a Drum—
No ſmutty Thought in doubtful Phraſe expreſt;
And, Gentlemen, if ſo, pray where's the Jeſt?
When we wou'd raiſe your Mirth, you hardly know,
Whether in ſtrictneſs you ſhou'd Laugh or no,
But turn upon the Ladies in the Pit,
And if they redden, you are ſure 'tis Wit.
Protect him then, ye Fair ones; for the Fair
Of all Conditions are his equal Care.
He draws a Widow, who of blameleſs Carriage
True to her Jointure, hates a ſecond Marriage;
